---
title: More digits!
date: 2019-07-11
tags: [SageMath, Octave, digits, numerical approximation]
---


[SageMath](http://www.sagemath.org/) has tons of powerful features (I explain [how to install the latest version on Debian *buster* in a previous note](/notes/sage/installsage)), one relatively simple and very handy function I've recently used is `numerical_approx()` (see [the documentation](http://doc.sagemath.org/html/en/reference/misc/sage/misc/functional.html)) that returns (suspense = 0) a numerical approximation for any number of digits!

In my case, I was looking for a 40 digits approximation of `4*pi/(6+sqrt(38))`. Using a programming language such as [R](https://www.r-project.org/), I would have had to tweak the printing format:

```R
4*pi/(6+sqrt(38))
[1] 1.033044
R> format(4*pi/(6+sqrt(38)), digits = 22)                                  
[1] "1.033043647749253723944"
```

and I would actually have been limited to 22 digits.

```R
R> format(4*pi/(6+sqrt(38)), digits = 23)                                  
Error in prettyNum(.Internal(format(x, trim, digits, nsmall, width, 3L,  :
  invalid 'digits' argument
```

SageMath is actually built to do number theory and handling tons of digits is actually what t does! So I can easily get a 40 digits approximation.

```python
sage: numerical_approx(4*pi/(6+sqrt(38)), digits = 40)
1.033043647749253740591407364288254970944
```

There is a very short alias `n()` for this function:

```python
sage: n(4*pi/(6+sqrt(38)), digits = 40)
1.033043647749253740591407364288254970944
```

and I can get way more digits!


```python
sage: n(4*pi/(6+sqrt(38)), digits = 4000)
1.
```

Sweet :sunglasses:!


I tend to use Sage more than Octave but I would like to mention that you can also use [Octave symbolic](https://octave.sourceforge.io/symbolic/) (use `apt-get install octave octave-syboclic` for with `apt` on Debian and Debian derivatives).

```matlab
pkg load symbolic
digits(100)
vpa(`pi`)
3.14159265358979323846264338327950288419716939937510582097494459230781640
  6286208998628034825342117068
% OK
vpa(4*pi/(6+sqrt(38)))
1.03304364774925372394420719501795247197151184082031250000000000000000000
  0000000000000000000000000000
% Not OK similar to R approx
vpa('4*pi/(6+sqrt(38))')
1.03304364774925374059140736428825497094410913342474880154737825907239698
  0381009839140666652799845660
% OK quotations marks matter, similar approx as SageMath!
```

That's all folks!
